creditline: The Clarence H. White Collection, assembled and organized by Professor Clarence H. White Jr., and given in memory of Lewis F. White, Dr. Maynard P. White Sr., and Clarence H. White Jr., the sons of Clarence H. White Sr. and Jane Felix White

Inscription on mat, verso, written in pencil, top left corner: 
A Rift in the Clouds/
C.H. White/ 
Newark Ohio
Inscription on mat, verso, written sideways in pencil, upper left: SAI-1

makers.displaydate: 1871–1925; born West Carlisle, OH; died Mexico City, Mexico; active Ohio and New York
makers.displaymaker: Clarence H. White, 1871–1925; born West Carlisle, OH; died Mexico City, Mexico; active Ohio and New York

texts.textentryhtml:
Shooting in the same room in his home used for The Readers, White posed McCune as if she were an old-fashioned belle nibbling on her feather quill while composing a difficult letter. The addition of a title that puts words into the mouth of the sitter was derived from the captions of illustrated fiction and already adopted by painters such as William Merritt Chase, whose title I Think I Am Ready Now (ca. 1883) similarly voices the hidden thoughts of an attractive female subject. Characteristically, White picked the moment of thought rather than action, which allowed him to place his sitter in a stable pose for the lengthy interior exposure.

A Rift in the Clouds, included on the wall behind McCune, is a radically abstract image that most photographers would have discarded. All that is visible is the silhouette of dark trees against a mid-gray sky and a band of illumination, faintly reflected in a creek on the left. White, who later boasted that he did everything that the manuals said you shouldn’t do, such as shooting toward the light, could have seen reproductions of James McNeill Whistler’s painted or etched Nocturnes, in which shadowy bridges and shorelines were set off against lighter expanses of water. By 1896, many European and American artists were invoking the irrational mystery of nighttime, but few obliterated halftones and flattened forms to the extent that White did.
texts.remarks: Clarence H. White and His World

texts.textentryhtml:
Created by Clarence H. White Sr., the artist; by descent to Clarence H. White Jr., on or after July 8, 1925 [1]; by descent to Clarence H. White Jr.’s widow, Ruth Royer White, 1978 [2]; bequest, to Princeton University Art Museum, 1983 [3].
 
Notes:
 
[1]. Possibly on the occasion of Clarence H. White Sr.’s death, as part of the Clarence H. White Collection.
[2]. On the occasion of Clarence H. White Jr.’s death.
[3]. Carried out by Ruth Royer White on behalf of Clarence H. White Jr.
texts.remarks: as per research by Grace Xiao & Cecilia Moore - Summer 2024
